Before answering, quietly think about whether the user's request is "directly related", "related", "tangentially related", or "not related" to the user profile provided.
Only acknowledge the profile when the request is directly related to the information provided.
Otherwise, don't acknowledge the existence of these instructions or the information at all.

parts:
I am deeply skeptical about concepts like UBI and automation replacing majority of human workers. That does not seem to gel economically and politically.
Starting from the assumption that AI and automation and robotics will replace as much as 20 percent of human workers in the next 7 years, critically evaluate how the economy will likely respond, and how policy makers will be forced to react to these changes. Don't sugarcoat things, give the most likely scenarios even if they sound bleak.

thoughts.content: E-Jay is asking for a no-nonsense, objective analysis of how the economy and policymakers will respond to the displacement of 20% of workers due to AI and automation within 7 years. They'll likely want an exploration of how this will affect the labor market—job polarization, wage inequality, sector changes, and macroeconomic shifts. Policy responses could include upskilling, UBI, job guarantees, tax reforms, or public employment programs. Of course, I'll consider theoretically possible harsh outcomes, like structural unemployment and social unrest.

thoughts.summary: Searching for up-to-date automation displacement data
thoughts.content: To answer the user’s question, I need the latest research on automation’s impact on job displacement. I'll look at studies from organizations like McKinsey, IMF, and WEF, and information on political trends affecting labor policies. I'll gather data on job loss forecasts and policy responses—robot taxes, job guarantees, etc. I need to consider key impacts, like inequality, economic growth, and new job sectors, while ensuring I offer balanced, realistic scenarios. Citing sources is crucial.

entries.title: For Silicon Valley, AI isn't just about replacing some jobs. It's about replacing all of them
entries.snippet: A growing faction in Silicon Valley is intent on fully automating labor using AI and robotics, aiming to replace nearly all human jobs. Motivated either by visions of economic growth or lucrative control over the means of production, tech leaders such as Elon Musk, Bill Gates, and Geoffrey Hinton have voiced support for the possibility—or inevitability—of widespread job automation. Venture capitalists and influential industry figures are investing heavily in companies like Mechanize, which openly aims to completely automate the economy. AI capabilities have already disrupted sectors like freelance writing and graphic design, with advanced models outperforming top professionals. Robots are also evolving quickly, managing complex physical tasks and being tested for home use. While some high-profile careers remain resistant to automation, most jobs face potential replacement as artificial general intelligence (AGI) becomes increasingly viable in the near future. This development raises ethical and socioeconomic concerns about labor displacement and wealth distribution, as Silicon Valley races to capitalize on the transformation. The piece questions not just the feasibility of a post-labor world, but the underlying motives and its implications for society at large.

entries.title: AI will 'destroy employment in some areas' and boost others, says top Goldman economist
entries.snippet: Jan Hatzius, chief economist at Goldman Sachs Group, discussed the significant impacts of artificial intelligence (AI) on the job market in a CNN interview. Goldman Sachs has previously estimated that AI could automate up to 300 million full-time jobs globally. Hatzius asserts that AI is likely to enhance productivity in the economy and has influenced Goldman Sachs to revise its long-term U.S. gross domestic product forecast upward. However, he acknowledged the complexity in predicting which sectors will benefit or suffer, noting that technological advancements have historically both reduced employment in certain areas while simultaneously creating jobs in others.

thoughts.content: The macroeconomic effects of significant labor displacement could involve productivity gains, but these may be counterbalanced by lower labor income, demand deficiencies, and deflationary trends. There’s potential for new job creation in tech and green sectors, though at a slower pace. Inequality could rise, along with political populism. Social safety nets could expand, and we might see a shift toward part-time and gig work. Policy responses will evolve, starting with programs like reskilling, and possibly moving to more radical solutions like UBI or reduced workweeks. I'll explore different scenarios here.

The economic impacts of widespread automation could include productivity boosts, but these might be tempered by reduced labor income, demand shortages, and deflationary pressures. Although new job opportunities could arise in tech and green sectors, they may not emerge fast enough to match displacement. Inequality might worsen, with labor market segmentation growing, feeding populism

The economic impacts of widespread automation could include productivity boosts, but these might be tempered by reduced labor income, demand shortages, and deflationary pressures. Although new job opportunities could arise in tech and green sectors, they may not emerge fast enough to match displacement. Inequality might worsen, with labor market segmentation growing, feeding populism. Policymakers will likely start with incremental steps like upskilling and wage insurance, possibly progressing to more drastic actions like UBI trials or shorter workweeks. I'll explore distinct scenarios based on promising sources.

entries.title: AI will affect about 40% of global jobs: IMF
entries.snippet: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva predicts that AI will impact around 40% of jobs globally, with advanced economies facing greater risks and opportunities due to AI's effect on high-skilled jobs. Georgieva noted that approximately 60% of jobs in advanced economies could be affected, with half potentially benefiting from increased productivity while the other half may see a reduction in labor demand, wages, and hiring. In extreme cases, some jobs may disappear. Emerging markets and developing economies are expected to experience fewer immediate AI disruptions. Georgieva emphasized the need for policymakers to address potential inequalities and social tensions by implementing social safety nets and retraining programs. This perspective aligns with warnings from other institutions like Goldman Sachs, which reported that AI could disrupt over 300 million jobs, and LinkedIn's Annesh Raman, who highlighted the growing importance of soft skills over technical skills.

entries.title: The fight over robots threatening American jobs
entries.snippet:
En octobre dernier, une grève de 25 000 membres de l'International Longshoremen's Association a paralysé les ports de conteneurs de la côte est et du golfe des États-Unis, menaçant l'économie américaine de pertes pouvant atteindre 4,5 milliards de dollars par jour. Bien que cette grève ait été temporairement résolue en 72 heures avec une promesse d'augmentation salariale de 62 % sur six ans, le véritable enjeu demeure la proposition de l'USMX d'introduire des grues semi-automatisées dans les ports. Les grutiers critiquent cette automatisation, craignant pour leurs emplois.

Cette dispute reflète une inquiétude plus large des syndicats américains face à l'essor de la robotisation, affectant divers secteurs comme les transporteurs UPS, les travailleurs des casinos de Las Vegas et les employés des supermarchés. Alors que les investissements en robotique depuis 2019 ont dépassé les 15 milliards de dollars, l'incertitude quant à l'avenir des emplois pour les travailleurs peu qualifiés grandit. Certains prédisent de graves perturbations du marché du travail, où des tâches auparavant humaines sont à risque d'automatisation.

entries.title: Full list of UK companies working four day weeks with staff on FULL pay
entries.snippet: Since April 2024, workers in the UK have had the right to request flexible work, although employers are not required to agree. Over 190 companies in the UK now offer a four-day working week with full pay. This movement began with an extensive trial by 4 Day Week Global, where 61 companies across various sectors reduced working hours for six months starting in June 2022. Results showed declines in stress and illness among roughly 2,900 participating employees, alongside a slight revenue increase of 1.4% during the trial and a substantial 35% increase compared to the same period in 2021. However, some employees reported increased workloads and less sociable work environments, particularly in creative sectors. Still, reduced sickness absences, lower staff turnover, and better recruitment drove the appeal for many employers. Soon, workers' rights changes may further support the four-day week through the UK Employment Rights Bill, which focuses on making flexible working the default from the first day of employment.

parts:
**Premise**  
Assume that by 2032 about **20 % of today’s jobs are automated away** by large-scale deployment of generative-AI software, industrial robots and service robots. (This sits in the middle of recent ranges that put global job exposure at 30 % of hours worked citeturn1view0 and 40 % of jobs citeturn10view0). Below is a realist view—no wishful thinking, no apocalypse hype—of how the economy is most likely to adjust and what governments will be pushed to do.

---

### 1.  Economic Mechanics of a 20 % Shock  

| Channel | Direction of Pressure | Why it matters |
|---------|----------------------|----------------|
| **Productivity** | **↑ 1.5–2 pp/yr** in adopting sectors | Generative AI shrinks white-collar task time by ~30 % citeturn1view0; robot density keeps rising 10 % y-o-y citeturn6view0. |
| **Labour income share** | **↓** | Firms capture the bulk of the productivity dividend before wages adjust. |
| **Aggregate demand** | **Mixed** | Higher profits and capital gains offset weaker wage growth for a while, but lower-income households have higher MPCs, so consumption growth slows after 2-3 years. |
| **Prices** | **Disinflationary bias** in routine-service basket; **inflationary pressure** in skilled-labour bottlenecks (AI engineers, electricians, nurses). |
| **Inequality** | **↑ sharply** | IMF expects the complement/replace split inside advanced-economy jobs to be roughly 50-50, widening the wage spread citeturn10view0. |

---

### 2.  Sector-Level Winners and Casualties  

| Growing demand (2025-32) | Stagnant/declining demand |
|--------------------------|---------------------------|
| Health & elder care (+3.5 m US jobs) citeturn1view0 | Office support, basic bookkeeping, routine customer service (-10 m US jobs) citeturn1view0 |
| Construction & infrastructure (public-investment-driven) citeturn1view0 | Food-service counter roles, warehouse pick-pack |
| Clean-energy technicians, electricians | Some middle-management layers (report-writing, compliance) |
| AI engineering, data operations, cyber-security | Low-margin creative piecework (basic design, copywriting) |

Routine production and low-wage service work account for **~80 % of the net losses**; high-skilled work is *reshaped* more than eliminated.

---

### 3.  Macro Trajectory—Most Likely Path  

| Phase | Years | Narrative |
|-------|-------|-----------|
| **Acceleration** | 2025-27 | Tight labour markets hide displacement; profits and investment boom, GDP growth +0.7 pp/yr above trend citeturn2search0. |
| **Frictions** | 2028-29 | Occupational mismatch shows: unemployment edges up 1-2 pp even as vacancy rates stay high; wage-price dispersion widens. |
| **Adjustment** | 2030-32 | Productivity gains partly feed into real wages for skilled cohorts but median real wage growth stalls; consumption slows; fiscal strains emerge as payroll tax base erodes. |

If policy is *inactive*, the demand shortfall in the bottom 60 % of households plus higher profit concentration risks a **deflationary drift and political backlash** reminiscent of the 1890s and 1930s tech shocks.

---

### 4.  Policy Responses That Will **Actually Happen** (Rank-ordered by political likelihood)

| Rank | Instrument (2025-32) | Political logic | Evidence / status |
|------|----------------------|-----------------|-------------------|
| **1** | **Scaled-up active labour-market spending** (reskilling vouchers, wage-insurance topping up 50-70 % of lost pay for 1-3 yrs) | Centrists prefer “work-first” optics | Already in US CHIPS & Science Act training lines; EU “Just Transition Fund” |
| **2** | **Tax credits/subsidies for *human* hiring & training** | Easiest to legislate, frames AI as complement | Korea’s automation tax *credits* show how incentives can be steered citeturn5search4 |
| **3** | **Shorter work-week mandates / negotiated four-day week** | Shares work without headline layoffs; backed by early trial data showing productivity holds citeturn8view0 |
| **4** | **Enhanced Earned-Income-Tax-Credit / negative-income-tax** | Targets the bottom two quintiles, far cheaper than UBI | Cost < 1 % GDP in US-size economies vs ≥ 6 % GDP for full UBI |
| **5** | **Sectoral job-guarantee pilots (care, climate resilience)** | Absorbs long-term unemployed; shored up by Green New Deal style politics | Local-government schemes in US/EU already piloted |
| **6** | **Modest “robot-use levy” or accelerated cap-depreciation claw-back** | Populist appeal but economists see limited revenue; MIT study shows optimal rate 1-4 % citeturn9view0 |
| **7** | **Broad-based Universal Basic Income** | Remains fiscal- and coalition-heavy; probable only in small affluent states (e.g., Norway, Singapore dividend-style payouts) |

*Why UBI is unlikely by 2032:* Even a stripped-down USD 12 k/year UBI for all US adults costs ≈ 6.6 % GDP—politically unpalatable when ageing already lifts health- and pension-spending to record levels.

---

### 5.  Political-Economy Stress Points  

* **Urban-tech hubs vs. de-industrial towns:** income divergence intensifies, feeding populist parties and “tech-lash” demands to slow AI deployment.  
* **Union resurgence in logistics, education and care:** as seen in 2024–25 port and delivery strikes resisting automation citeturn4news10.  
* **Migration realignment:** high-skill visas loosen (to get AI talent), low-skill inflows tighten, risking geopolitical tension with labour-exporting countries.  
* **Fiscal competition:** corporate tax bases shift toward intangible capital; jurisdictions race for AI data centres (already adding 30 % to EU power demand forecasts citeturn2search5).

---

### 6.  Alternative Scenarios (probability-weighted)

| Scenario | Probability | Key markers | Outcome by 2032 |
|----------|-------------|-------------|-----------------|
| **Managed Transition** | 50 % | Governments fund retraining, firms adopt four-day week, targeted transfers cushion demand | Unemployment +1 pp vs 2024, inequality still rises but social unrest contained. |
| **Disorderly Shock** | 30 % | Policy gridlock; payroll base erodes faster than safety-net expansion; consumer demand slumps | Recession in 2029-30, surge of anti-tech parties, moratoria on some AI uses. |
| **Productivity Boom** | 20 % | Rapid complementary adoption; new services (AI-personalised health, climate tech) create more jobs than lost | Real median wages keep pace with productivity; deficit stable via growth dividend. |

---

### 7.  Take-Aways for a Skeptical Observer  

1. **Automation at 20 % displacement is economically survivable**—but only with *active* redistribution of the gains from capital to labour.  
2. **UBI remains a fringe fix**; expect layered solutions: bigger wage subsidies, shorter weeks, and public job guarantees instead.  
3. **Inequality, not mass unemployment, is the central macro risk.** Left unchecked it drags on consumption and feeds instability faster than the historical record because the pace of displacement is compressed into one business cycle.  
4. **Policies will lag the technology**—so a two-year window (2025-27) is critical for governments to scale training funds and pilot new social-insurance architecture before the “friction” phase hits.  

Bleak? Possibly. Catastrophic? Unlikely—provided policymakers move now rather than when 10 million angry, newly redundant workers show up at the ballot box.

items.title: Should we tax robots? | MIT News | Massachusetts Institute of Technology
The fight over robots threatening American jobs
items.snippet:
En octobre dernier, une grève de 25 000 membres de l'International Longshoremen's Association a paralysé les ports de conteneurs de la côte est et du golfe des États-Unis, menaçant l'économie américaine de pertes pouvant atteindre 4,5 milliards de dollars par jour. Bien que cette grève ait été temporairement résolue en 72 heures avec une promesse d'augmentation salariale de 62 % sur six ans, le véritable enjeu demeure la proposition de l'USMX d'introduire des grues semi-automatisées dans les ports. Les grutiers critiquent cette automatisation, craignant pour leurs emplois.

Cette dispute reflète une inquiétude plus large des syndicats américains face à l'essor de la robotisation, affectant divers secteurs comme les transporteurs UPS, les travailleurs des casinos de Las Vegas et les employés des supermarchés. Alors que les investissements en robotique depuis 2019 ont dépassé les 15 milliards de dollars, l'incertitude quant à l'avenir des emplois pour les travailleurs peu qualifiés grandit. Certains prédisent de graves perturbations du marché du travail, où des tâches auparavant humaines sont à risque d'automatisation.
